articles.headline: Hostility Has Its Rewards
articles.snippet: In Silicon Valley, where entrepreneurialism is a religion, people have long taken a dim view of acquisitions.
articles.abstract: In Silicon Valley, where entrepreneurialism is a religion, people have long taken a dim view of acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif.  “It’s crazy to say you will only grow through innovation,” Larry Ellison, the hard-charging chief executive of Oracle, was telling me last week. “It’s bizarre that there’s a stigma to buying something rather than building it yourself.”

articles.headline: Bomber Kills 5 U.S. Soldiers in Iraq’s Capital
articles.snippet: The attack was the deadliest on American soldiers in Baghdad since the height of the troop buildup.
articles.abstract: The attack was the deadliest on American soldiers in Baghdad since the height of the troop buildup.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A man walked up to a group of American soldiers on foot patrol in an upscale shopping district in central Baghdad on Monday and detonated the explosives-filled vest he was wearing, killing five soldiers and wounding three others and an Iraqi interpreter who accompanied them.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Buyout Industry Staggers Under Weight of Debt
articles.snippet: Celebrated buyout firms like Blackstone, hailed only a year ago for its deal-making prowess, are seeing their profits collapse as the credit crisis spreads.
articles.abstract: Celebrated buyout firms like Blackstone, hailed only a year ago for its deal-making prowess, are seeing their profits collapse as the credit crisis spreads.
articles.lead_paragraph: With their big paydays and bigger egos, private equity moguls came to symbolize an era of hyper-wealth on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Grappling With New Risk
articles.snippet: After being welcomed back to the bank a few years ago, John J. Mack faces questions about his ability to lead.
articles.abstract: After being welcomed back to the bank a few years ago, John J. Mack faces questions about his ability to lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: John J. Mack stood before his board and shareholders at Morgan Stanley’s 2007 annual meeting and struck an aggressive tone. Coming off a year of record profits fueled by using the firm’s capital to take some highly lucrative risks  particularly by diving deeply into subprime mortgages, leveraged loans and complex derivatives  Mr. Mack had much to celebrate.

articles.headline: Paying at the Pump, in a Big Way
articles.snippet: When half a tank costs $505, rising fuel prices sting. While the price of gasoline may be on the verge of setting another record, diesel is already there.
articles.abstract: When half a tank costs $505, rising fuel prices sting. While the price of gasoline may be on the verge of setting another record, diesel is already there.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND  Ricardo Caraballo was having a familiar American experience at the filling station the other day, groaning as the pump clicked up, up, up. By the time he finished it read $505, and his tank was only half full.

articles.headline: Pace of Change Too Slow to Keep Entrepreneurs in France
articles.snippet: Economists say France will have to make much deeper changes to its culture’s attitude toward capitalism if it intends to keep young entrepreneurs at home.
articles.abstract: Economists say France will have to make much deeper changes to its culture’s attitude toward capitalism if it intends to keep young entrepreneurs at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Four years ago, Caroline Sivilia, a Parisian who worked for the ad agency Publicis Groupe, left France to start a magazine for French people living in London.

articles.headline: Boeing Says It Will Protest Tanker Deal
articles.snippet: The G.A.O. would have 100 days to review the action, which can be expected to stoke a debate about American jobs and military competitiveness in an election year.
articles.abstract: The G.A.O. would have 100 days to review the action, which can be expected to stoke a debate about American jobs and military competitiveness in an election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Boeing said Monday that it would protest the Air Force’s award of a $35 billion contract to build aerial refueling planes to a group that includes its European rival Airbus.
articles.byline: By Jeff Bailey and David M. Herszenhorn
